Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RNMS: Kinetic Description of Emerging Challenges in Multiscale Problems of Natural Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a Research Network in Mathematical Sciences: ?Kinetic description of emerging challenges in multiscale problems of natural sciences? (KI-net). Kinetic descriptions have traditionally played a central role in many areas of mathematical physics. In the last two decades, however, kinetic descriptions have emerged as an indispensable tool for a quantitative description of diverse phenomena, ranging from semi-conductors, polymers and plasma, to cell migrations, swarming, and neuron networks, as well as traffic, social and economic networking. It is in this context that the KI-net will foster cross-fertilization between mathematics and other scientific disciplines, with particular focus on the following three areas:
* Quantum dynamics with applications to chemistry;
* Network dynamics with applications to social sciences; and
* Kinetic models of biological processes.

The principal objectives are to foster new kinetic-based national and international collaborations; to train a future generation of researchers to address new challenges, and to sustain the United-States? leading role on the international stage in this field. The proposed KI-net will bring the full range of mathematical techniques to bear on important scientific challenges in kinetic descriptions of new phenomena in physical, biological and social sciences. The ultimate goal is the development, analysis and computation of novel kinetic descriptions with various applications in these disciplines. KI-net will offer a unique platform to carry out these objectives. It will be centered around three hubs: the Center for Scientific Computation & Math Modeling (CSCAMM) in the University of Maryland, the Institute for Computational and Engineering Science (ICES) at UT Austin, and the Department of Mathematics at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. At the initial stage, they will inter-connect 12 nodes through a series of edges, involving 25 core participants.

KI-net Research Network home page: http://www2.cscamm.umd.edu/ki-net/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From the smallest physical scale to the biggest, the world is respectively characterized by the quantum, classical, statistical, and fluid mechanics. The corresponding mathematical descriptions are Schroedinger, Newton, Boltzmann, and Euler (Navier-Stokes) equations. While physicists use different descriptions in different regimes, we are concerned with unifying the theories for a universal description. In this five-year project, we systematically addressed the related modeling, analysis, and computation challenges. The network composes of three major hubs: University of Maryland, University of Texas-Austin and University of Wisconsin-Madison. We only report outcome achieved in UW-Madison here.

During the course of the support, UW-Madison served as the hub, and CalTech, ORNL, Yale, UIC, ISU, UCSB and SJTU served as nodes. We altogether hosted numerous activities including larger-sized conferences, and small-sized “interaction team” collaboration. Most of the activities are either open to, or partially or fully attended by young researchers. Here is the list of supported large-sized conferences:

 

1. 2012 Young Researchers Workshop, Oct, 2012, UW-Madison

2. Workshop on Kinetic PDEs: Analysis and Computation, Apr, 2013, ISU

3. Summer School on Mathematical and Computational Methods in Quantum Dynamics, Aug , 2013, UW-Madison

4. Mathematical and Numerical Methods for Complex Quantum Systems, Mar, 2014, UIC

5 Dynamics and Numerics for Non-local PDEs and Related Equations in the Physical and Biological Sciences, May, 2014, ISU

6. Uncertainty quantification in kinetic and hyperbolic problems, Mar 28, 2015, UW-Madison

7. Asymptotic Preserving and Multiscale Methods for Kinetic and Hyperbolic Problems, May, 2015, UW-Madison

8 Workshop and Summer School on Kinetic Equations and Gas Dynamics, Aug, 2015, Shanghai Jiaotong University

9. Scalable methods for kinetic equations, Oct, 2015, ORNL

10. Boundary Value Problems and Multiscale Coupling Methods for Kinetic Equations, Apr, 2016, UW-Madison

11. Mathematical and Computational Methods in Quantum Chemistry, May, 2016, Yale

12. Summer School on Quantum and Kinetic Theory for Complex Systems, Jun, 2016, UCSB

13. New Trends in Quantum and Classical Kinetic Equations and Related PDEs, Oct, 2016, UW-Madison

14. Mean-field modeling and multiscale methods for complex physical and biological systems, Oct, 2016, UCSB

15. Kinetic Descriptions of Chemical and Biological Systems: Models, Analysis and Numerics, Mar, 2017, ISU

16. Mathematical and Physical Aspects of Topologically Protected States, May, 2017, UW-Madison

17. Hypocoercivity and Sensitivity Analysis in Kinetic Equations and Uncertainty Quantification, Oct, 2017, UW-Madison

18. Kinetic and related models with applications in the natural sciences, Apr, 2018, UW-Madison

19. Recent progress in analytical aspects of kinetic equations and related fluid models, Sep, 2019, UW-Madison

20. Forward and Inverse Problems in Kinetic Theory, Oct, 2019, UW-Madison

We always kept an eye on the core theoretical development in kinetic theory, and numerous lectures and seminars were organized. Conferences on boundary layer analysis, mean-field analysis and a summary type conferences were organized to review the development of the core kinetic theory during the past seven years (conference No. 10, 14 and 19 respectively). Numerical studies of kinetic equations were also strengthened, see No. 7, 9, 11 and 17 above. There were conferences that are relatively general to incorporate both theory and numerics, see No. 2, 3, 8, 10, 12, and 13. Besides working on the core of kinetic theory, we drew connections and collaborations with chemists, physicists, biologists and engineers working in similar areas. Conferences were organized to address problems in quantum chemistry, chemical and biological systems and general natural sciences: No. 4, 5, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15, 16 and 18 above. The two conferences hosted in Oak Ridge National Lab (computing division) and Yale University (chemistry department) especially reflected such collaboration. With forward thinking in mind, we explored the connection of kinetic theory with new subareas in general mathematics: special attention was paid to uncertainty quantification and inverse problems, see No. 6, 17 and 20. Such exploration and collaboration with other communities triggered novel ideas and brought mutual benefits to both sides.

The project supported collaboration and allowed us to strengthen our connections with mathematicians around the globe. It not only strongly boosted the progress and development of kinetic theory in American, allowing the US to finally catch up with the progress made in other parts of the world (mainly the EU), putting some of US institutions (such as UMD, Brown, UW-Madison and UT-Austin) at the competing level with peer institutions that were traditionally well-known in the area, but also promoted the progress of kinetic theory overall. In a timely manner, the openness nature of the project allowed us to push forward the study of general PDE and computational mathematics overall. Numerous young researchers have been trained through the project. The funding provided by the grant allowed young researchers to participate in activities, be exposed to the newest research development, and present their own most recent research results. At least ten young researchers in kinetic theory found faculty/postdoc positions during the past few years.
